message_1: In a class of 30 students, how many ways can a teacher choose a group of 5 students to participate in a math competition?
message_2:
To determine the number of ways a teacher can choose a group of 5 students from a class of 30, we use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of students (30 in this case) and k is the number of students to be chosen (5 in this case). The exclamation mark represents the factorial of a number.

C(30, 5) = 30! / (5!(30-5)!)

C(30, 5) = 30! / (5!25!)

Now, we calculate the factorials:

30! = 30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26 × 25!
5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1
25! = 25 × 24 × 23 × ... × 2 × 1

Now, we can simplify the expression:

C(30, 5) = (30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26) / (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1)

C(30, 5) = (30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26) / 120

C(30, 5) = 142506

So, there are 142,506 ways for the teacher to choose a group of 5 students from a class of 30 students to participate in a math competition.
